prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: In LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[1] the Supreme Court agreed that the threefold test for a fiduciary relationship was applicable. However, two different views were raised regarding the necessity of vulnerability as an ingredient in a fiduciary relationship.

Sopinka J., speaking for the majority of the court, held that vulnerability is the most significant characteristic of a fiduciary relationship. He relied on the decision of the Australian court in Hospital Products Ltd. v. U.S. Surgical Corp.[2] In the Hospital Products case, Dawson J. stated that “the notion underlines all the cases of fiduciary obligation that, inherent in the nature of the relationship itself is a position of disadvantage or vulnerability”. This idea was also emphasized in Guerin v. Canada,[3] which cited Professor Weinrib's comment that “the hallmark of a fiduciary relation is that the relative legal positions are such that one party is at the mercy of the other's discretion”.

Sopinka J. in LAC Minerals held that misuse of confidential information alone does not create a fiduciary duty, but is more properly characterized as a breach of confidence. However, La Forest J. in dissent held that, in his view, vulnerability was not a necessary ingredient in every fiduciary relationship. La Forest J. referred to the following quote from Wilson J. in Frame v. Smith: “… vulnerability arises from the inability of the beneficiary … to prevent the injurious exercise of the power or discretion combined with the … absence of other legal or practical remedies to redress the wrongful exercise of the discretion or power”.[4] La Forest J. argued that vulnerability is not crucial since fiduciary obligations can be breached without harm being inflicted on the beneficiary. He cited Keech v. Sandford[5] as an example. Not only is actual harm unnecessary, but susceptibility to harm will not be present in many cases.

The Supreme Court of Canada was again asked to address the issue of breach of fiduciary duty in Hodgkinson v. Simms.[6] In that case, La Forest J. characterized the existence of a fiduciary duty as a “‘power-dependency’ relationship [which] describes any situation where one party, by statute, agreement, a particular course of conduct, or by unilateral undertaking, gains a position of overriding power or influence over another party”.[7]
However, in the same case, Sopinka J. held that the distinguishing feature of a fiduciary relationship is whether:

… that power or discretion [can] be exercised unilaterally, that is, without the consent of the other … can the powerless party be said to be “peculiarly vulnerable” or “at the mercy of” the party who holds the power …
… the law has imposed a fiduciary obligation only at the extreme of total reliance.[8]
